Bair, a native of Pittsburgh, is entering Krystal Epps his third year of coaching for the Panthers.

In just two seasons, he has coached the team to becoming a dominating middle and long distance force in the Big East Conference. Last season he coached his son to an All-America finish at the NCAA Outdoor Championships and a ninth-place finish at the regional cross coun- try championships. Coach Bair was an integral part of the team s success in 2006, having three middle distance runners qualify for the regional cham- pionships in the 1,500 meters and coaching the men s cross country team to its best regional finish to date. In his first season at Pitt, Coach Bair helped lead the men s cross country team to a seventh-place finish in the Big East Championships and a ninth place-finish at the NCAA Regional Championships. He also helped coach the women s cross country team to a seventh-place finish at the Big East Championships and an eighth-place finish at the NCAA Regional Championships. Coach Bair was integral in coaching the men s track and field team to a second-place finish in the 1,500 meters in both Indoor and Outdoor Big East Championships. Demetreus Darden Bintu Sherif Ted Dworek Academic Support Academic Support Strength Conditioning 66666 22222000000000066666-----0000077777 PPPPPIIIIITTTTTTTTTT TTTTTRRRRRAAAAACCCCCKKKKK AAAAANNNNNDDDDD FFFFFIIIIIEEEEELLLLLDDDDD CCCCCRRRRROOOOOSSSSSSSSSS CCCCCOOOOOUUUUUNNNNNTTTTTRRRRRYYYYY 12672PittTxt.pmd 6 10 4 2006, 10 22 AMTRIBUTE TO JOHN WOODRUFF CELEBRATING JOHN WOODRUFF AND THE 70TH ANNIVERSARY OF HIS OLYMPIC GOLD The 1930 s were a turbulent time not only in America but across the world. The United States was in the midst of the Depression. Nazi Germany was gaining power throughout Europe. And in 1936, a very tense world turned its attention to Berlin and the Olympic games. That same year, a young man from Connellsville, Pennsylvania, arrived at the University of Pittsburgh destined to make history. As a freshman, John Woodruff immediately won gold at the Penn Re- lays and NCAA Championships. His amazing jour- ney had only just begun as he found himself as one of only 12 African-American members of the United States Olympic Team.

Woodruff s incredible story continued over to the 800 meters, where he made one of the most in- credible moves ever seen in Olympic competition. He became the first African-American runner to win a gold medal at the 1936 Olympics. And had it not been for the World War II, he may have won many more. He entered the military in 1941 after graduating from Pitt with a degree in sociology in 1939. He also served during the Korean War. True to form, he spent his career in the service of others. His humble demeanor away from the track belied his dominance as an athlete on the track. While at Pitt he won three national collegiate championships, four IC4A championships and held the world record in the half-mile. As fate would have it, Woodruff suffered the amputation of both of his legs five years ago due to circulatory problems and a broken hip. This year, Not that the feet made the man, nor on this 70th anniversary of the Berlin Olympics we even his feat. Quicksilver athletes come pay tribute to John Woodruff s athletic ability and and go.

Gold medalists fade. What determination to succeed. differentiated Mr. Woodruff was the force, the determination... Its men s and women s teams boast 10 Olympians, the most by any Panther sports program. Pitt s track and field teams have produced a pair of gold FRANK SHEA medalists John Woodruff, who won the 800 meters at the 1936 United States of America Games in Berlin, and Roger Kingdom, who won the 110 meter high 1920 440 Meters hurdles in both the 1984 and 1988 Olympics in Los Angeles and DAN GWINN Seoul respectively. Another Pittsburgh product, Herb Douglas, earned United States of America a bronze medal in the long jump at the 1948 Games in London. 1928 Hammer Throw Pitt s Olympians have come from near and far. Woodruff, who lives in Arizona, was from nearby Connellsville, Pa. Kingdom came VIC PICKARD to Pittsburgh as a prized running back football recruit out of Unadilla, Canada Ga. Najuma Fletcher, one of the most decorated athletes in Pitt his- 1928 Pole Vault tory and former assistant coach, was one of three representatives of her native Guyana to participate in the 1992 Olympics in Barcelona. JOHN WOODRUFF More recently, Ayne Allen represented St. Kitts at the 1996 Atlanta United States of America Games.

One of Pitt s most familiar Olympians, Arnie Sowell went to 1936 800 Meters (Gold Medal) high school just blocks from the Cathedral of Learning at Schenley High. Sowell finished fourth in the 800 meters at the 1956 Games in HERB DOUGLAS Melbourne.
